Fields.DialogueText: Hurry! Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
I think that's the last of them. Belfast, how's the infirmary holding up?
Well, everyone's overworked and exhausted, and supplies are stretched thin.
Apart from that.
I... don't think we're going to lose anyone from that fight, if that's what you're asking?
Very good. So... if that's not what's bothering you, what is?
Bothering me? Oh, nothing. I'm just a bit distracted.
By what?
Dolphins. They're odd creatures.
Huh. Okay. Now, I would've guessed it was the religious question on your mind, but... sure, dolphins are good too.
Nobody's asked me any questions. The divinity student isn't even here yet.
Sure, but we've all seen you with that Bible since you first got her letter. You have to have been thinking about it.
A bit, but not really. I mean, I'm not quite sure exactly what I am, in a metaphysical sense, but... well, do you think I'm an angel?

Fields.MenuText: No.
No comment.
Depends. I give you orders, so would that make me God?

Fields.DialogueText: Right. Though, disturbingly emphatic.
Well, I'm not.
I think it would actually make you extremely presumptuous. So you're lucky I'm not.
My life is complicated enough just being me. I don't think delusions of grandeur would help.
I think Miss Sheridan will be interesting to talk to, though. She seems clever.
We can continue this later. I don't know exactly what I'm hearing in the water, but I really want to listen.
*ALARM*
Belfast, I take it this is the new arrival?
Yes! Captain, meet Joanna Sheridan, from Queen's University, Belfast. Joanna, meet the Captain.
Oh. Hullo?
I'm sorry. My ears are still ringing a bit from the massive explosions.
I'm Joanna. Hi.
And you're here to determine if my ship's living embodiment is supernatural.
Angelic. You don't think it's a fair question?

Fields.MenuText: Totally fair.
I asked her myself the other day. I could've sent you her answer by telegram.
I just get nervous when people bring up religious controversies on a warship under my command.

Fields.DialogueText: If a bit too flattering.
Captain, I really don't mind...
Oh. Oh, dear. I actually hadn't thought of that. I promise, we'll keep our talks to ourselves.
Captain, I know this is all very strange, and I know my godfather pulled strings to get me here, which wasn't really proper. But, I promise, I won't cause any fuss.
Oh, and would anyone like shortcake? I brought... well, several pounds, really.
Okay, you can stay for a while.
Yay!
Courage, crew! These Morganas will not spoil our guest's welcome!
@BATTLE
Belfast. Miss Sheridan. I hate to interrupt the conversation, but we are just about to engage the enemy.
Joanna can stay on the bridge, though, can't she? Captain? She won't be in the way.
You're getting along, I take it?
Um. If there's any reason to believe my being here could get us all killed, I think I'd rather err on the side of...
Sorry. Too late, now. Just hold onto something and try not to scream unless the rest of us start first.
@BATTLE
I think we're clear! Somebody start getting me damage reports!
We're fine.
You just know? She just knows?

Fields.MenuText: She just knows.
I know. It's creepy.

Fields.DialogueText: It's the same as you two knowing your feet haven't been blown off. It's all just part of me.
It is not. Nothing about me is creepy!
This is really very strange.
Does it hurt? You've never said.
What?
When the ship... when you get shot up. You've never said if it hurts.
It's not so bad. I appreciate that you try to keep it to a minimum, though.

Fields.MenuText: She's even got a favorite gun.

Fields.DialogueText: I do not! That'd be like having a favorite hand.
Oh, look. It's more Morganas.
And more strange dolphins.
Wait, is that what you were talking about the other day? You think dolphins are related to the Morganas? That's... unexpected.
Not dolphins in general. They're mostly about play and, well, adult pastimes. When they're not scared out of their minds.
But there are some strange ones out there.
We can talk later. I think the Morganas are about to start shooting at us.

Fields.MenuText: Duly noted. Steer clear of the dolphins.
Well, shoot back at them first!
Isn't that always the way?

Fields.DialogueText: They're smart, Captain. They'll swim for safety.
Okay!
Aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
Everyone keep your eyes open, but I think we're done for now.
Belfast, tell me more about the dolphins.
I can't tell you much. It's just that there are some dolphins out there that follow Morganas instead of running away from them.
And it's new.
There's kind of a hum to them, too. It's just... strange.
Everything's strange. Letting ourselves feel surprised is starting to feel self-indulgent.
Okay, keep listening for them. This is a new priority. If Morganas are messing with sea life, we need to know everything we can about it.
Yes, Captain.
Sorry, Miss Sheridan, I'm afraid your question and answer session will have to wait today. The lady of the house is listening for dolphins.
Dolphins?
Long story.
Do you mind if I ask how it's been going? You wanted to figure out whether the Belles are technically angels. Do you have a case to make to the King and Archbishop?
Do you? You know her better than I do.
I don't know about that. She actually likes you very much.
She likes you, too. And you're evading the question.

Fields.MenuText: I have no clue.
When I envision Gabriel in the Annunciation, I don't see him looking like Belfast.
My money's on space aliens. All of 'em.

Fields.DialogueText: At least you're honest.
I grant you, several Renaissance artists would have been taken aback.
Ah. Well, that would be outside my field of expertise.
You know they seem to speak every human language? The Belles, I mean.
They speak to Germans in German, Brits in English, Americans in bad English...
Funny. They're not all omniglots, though.
But some were polyglots from day one. One might say they're just outside the Curse of Babel.
Is that what you say?
Me? Why, Captain, I'm totally agnostic.
What does she say?
You know, I haven't gotten around to asking that one yet. We've spent a lot of time trying to figure out if she has free will.
Huh.
Sorry to interrupt. Captain, we need you to help us defeat some Morganas.
@BATTLE
Captain?
The Morganas? I see them.
There are dolphins between us and them. Unusual dolphins.
Of course there are. Do we need a live capture?
I don't think so. I just want to get close and get a good look before they scatter.
So you're proposing we just charge the Morgana fleet?
... It sounded more reasonable the way I said it.
All ahead full, Belfast. And pay attention. I don't want to have to do this twice.
@BATTLE
Belfast, tell me we got more out of that than just the ringing in our ears.
I think so, Captain. I'm positive that the dolphins have been surgically altered, and I...
Hold on. Surgically altered to do what? Are they being turned into torpedoes, or...?
It's more likely that they're spies. I'm seeing improvements to their senses, maybe radio-telepathic grafts to their brains...

Fields.MenuText: Huh.
Wow. I now have an entirely new category of nightmare to look forward to.
Can we use any of this ourselves?

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly.
You might want to hang onto "An Entirely New Category of Nightmare" as a title for your memoirs. Just a thought.
Oh, I hope not.
The technology's unstable and... well, weird. I'm not sure it even works very well. Seems more like experiments than a fleshed-out program.
Is that why they're keeping close to the Morgana fleets instead of stalking us? I mean, if they're meant to be spies, their priorities are odd.
I don't know.
But, I would really like to find the place where the Morganas are doing this, and to blow it up. Poor dolphins.
Hello, Belfast. Miss Sheridan. How's the dolphin hunt going?
I'm still not sure I get what we're doing.
Well, we're trying to identify dolphins that have been... abused by Morganas. Even if we can't help them, we can get a sense of how long it's been since they had surgery.
That will hopefully give us a sense of the maximum distance they could have traveled from the place where this was done to them.
The more data we get, the better our odds of figuring out exactly where this facility is, so that Belfast here can punch holes in it.
I can't just rely on revelation, I'm afraid.
Unless that was how you noticed they'd been afflicted in the first place.
Don't even start with me, Joanna.
Belfast has made some very strong arguments that she isn't an angel, Captain, and she's afraid I'm going to try to undermine them.
It starts with etymology. "Angel" from "angelus," Latin for messenger. Belles aren't messengers. We have no particular insight into any divine plans.
One could compare what you're doing to, say, the role of Archangel Michael in Revelation. Sometimes leading the fight is the message.

Fields.MenuText: I do believe I'm about ready for a break from this.
Stop teasing her, Joanna.
Belfast? Your response?

Fields.DialogueText: There should be coffee ready soon, Captain. Anyway...
She wouldn't know what to do with herself, Captain. Anyway...
Hey, I'm getting to it!
Not that I think you think I'm really angelic, Joanna – but if you did, I'd say it's presumptuous to think you know better than I do what I am.
Did that make sense?
I think I'd have to write it out to be sure.
Yes. It made sense.
No fun, Captain.
Um, Captain? I think we're coming up on Morganas...
@BATTLE
CAPTAIN!
I'm here! What's the... Morganas!
We were following a pod of altered dolphins. They...
They figured out that we're onto them. I think they led us into an ambush!
Nothing for it but to fight our way out. Get everyone to their positions – this is going to be a mess.
@BATTLE
I think we're clear of them. Belfast?
A lot of people were hurt, Captain. A lot.

Fields.MenuText: Damn Morganas.
It could've been worse.
Don't waste time worrying about it. Figure out who you can help first.

Fields.DialogueText: We won't let this happen again, Captain. I promise.
True. I'm going to see if I can expedite some things...
Yes, Captain. Right.
Hello, Captain. Hello, Belfast.
Not a good time to have a civilian on the bridge, Miss Sheridan.
We're trying to find the base where the Morganas are experimenting on dolphins. They know we're coming.
And you think it's stationary? It's not just another one of their ships?
We think so, yes. It's kind of...
Belfast, Morganas!
I see them.
Miss Sheridan, you've got time to get to your quarters before the shooting starts, but you need to move quickly.
@BATTLE
All clear.
I think the crew's okay, Captain. Some bruises, maybe, but we were lucky.

Fields.MenuText: Lucky is good.
That was skill, Belfast. Don't be modest.
Luck is the universe's way of getting your guard down. It makes me nervous.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I quite prefer it to "stoic in the face of disaster."
You say "modest," I say "avoiding hysterical laughter to keep from upsetting the crew."
Every so often you make me wonder what kind of childhood you must have had.
Anyway. I've been thinking about this Morgana facility. Assuming it exists...
I think it's a safe bet.
Yeah. I think we may want to try to get people inside it instead of just shooting at it from a distance. Steal everything we can get our hands on.
It feels like we're fighting blind nine-tenths of the time, and I'm sick of it.
Oh. Well... that should be a nightmare. But we'll be up against a worse one if we don't have this one.
Always glad when we're on the same page.
It's not on any maps.
I know! But it's there! The biplanes confirmed it!

Fields.MenuText: Maybe it's not an island. A platform? A bunch of ships lashed together?

Fields.DialogueText: Whatever it is, it doesn't seem to be moving.
And the ships that are guarding it aren't coming after us.
Which is good, given their numbers. Right?
I don't know. I think we may be looking at an anvil. Which means there's a hammer coming from somewhere.
We're not hearing anything from any of the mist zones, Captain.
Still... pull back. We don't have the numbers here to accomplish anything, and we have to make sure that word gets back that this thing is out here.
Yes, Captain.
Oh. There they are. Lots of noise from the southwest!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Have we ruled out its being an illusion?

Fields.DialogueText: I can't decide whether that would be worse.

Fields.MenuText: Have you checked for interference?

Fields.DialogueText: Ugh... that would be vile. But they're beyond the reach of the facility.
Hurry! Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
I think that's the last of them. Belfast?
Agreed. We're clear.
Are you sure we can't make a run on the island ourselves? I did pretty well with evasion in Operation Hipper!
I know. I read Captain Scott's reports. This is a little different, though.
... I just feel like I could be doing more.
You're doing plenty. Just check the debris out in the water.
I know. But... listen, I've been talking to Joanna. I know I'm not an angel, but what if I do have a purpose? I mean, what if it is this? It's possible, isn't it?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not asking our crew to do anything suicidal until you show me at least one burning bush.
Even if it is, that doesn't mean we should be reckless. We move when we have reinforcements.
I think you're overthinking this.

Fields.DialogueText: I think, contextually, you're more likely to be swallowed by a whale on the way to Jaffa. But I take your point.
I didn't mean that I wanted to plow alone into an enemy flotilla.
Probably.
It just feels like we're winning a lot of little fights and none of the big ones, you know?
Please don't complain about winning little fights. You'll jinx us.
Ooh, you're right. Careful what you wish for, and all that...
Ladies, is everything okay?
Captain, did you know she's never actually been to Belfast?
Well, that's not...
Walking around.
Belles don't really leave the ships. The ships are us.
That's right, you said that before. But there are all those pictures of Bulldog at the Tower of London and...
Artistic license.
Bulldog. Ugh. She's my sister and I love her, but she's totally lost her sense of perspective.
"Oh, you'll never know the crushing responsibility of being Britain's hero!"
I think Bulldog's brilliant. I wish we could set her on Hitler, too.

Fields.MenuText: Besides, somebody has to do it. And you would hate being the symbol-of-the-nation Belle. Hate. It.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly. Because I don't need the attention.
Fine. Bulldog's brilliant.
You'll feel better when we finally rendezvous with...
Morganas. Starboard. Intercept in eight minutes.
All hands to action stations!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Solve a lot of problems, wouldn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose I'm comfortable letting her save the world... even if she'd lord it over us for the rest of her career.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't there some way to get one of you Belles on land? Take a piece of you, maybe?

Fields.DialogueText: Can we volunteer Bulldog, Captain? Can I pick the piece while we're at it?
Hurry! Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
All clear. Well done, everyone.
I think it's very unfair that the Morganas get reinforcements so much more often than we do.

Fields.MenuText: Our people are gathering at Scapa Flow. It won't be too much longer.
Agreed.
But, think of how much more satisfying it'll be when we win!

Fields.DialogueText: I know. And Joanna's due to leave, as well.
Fair point. Shame Joanna's leaving before that point.
And after it's all done, I suppose we'll be taking Joanna back home.
We probably should've done it days ago. The timing's just been...
Yes.
Do you think she'll write?
She'd better at least send money. I've been destroying her at poker, and the IOUs are stacking up.
I'm serious. She's the only person on board who talks to me like I'm a real person, apart from you.
She'll write.
You know you're not allowed to leave, right? Permanently, I mean. I would be forced to exercise my Belle's veto.
I don't think you actually get one of those.
I'd find a way, Captain.
And somebody once tried to argue that you didn't have free will. Well, don't worry. I'm not going anywhere.
That's all I need to know.
Make sure the marines are ready. I don't think we're going to get a second chance at this.
They're ready, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: They'd better be.
Well, yes. Royal Marines. Probably went without saying.
Make sure they know I thought they might not be. I want 'em pissed off.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, I don't often tell you that you need to relax, but...
Quite.
I think our cook already took care of that.
Okay. Our friends hit them from the west; we come in from the east. We clear a path for the boys to hit shore, we give them as much cover as we can, we...
Captain. Morganas.
Where?
They're already trying to cannibalize the western contingent.
Okay. The game is afoot.
@BATTLE
Captain, they're dispersing. We've...
Oh, my...
Is that a volcano?
No.
No, that's an island self-destructing.
Dammit, we need to rescue the amphibious units! Belfast, get us moving!
Captain? What's the word?
Most of the Morgana fleet that was here seems to be heading straight for the Outer Hebrides. Our friends are trying to discourage them.
Captain... they're not enough. Some of them are damaged. They...
Our orders are to clear away whatever Morganas are still around.
We do it fast, we salvage what technology we can, and then we join on the intercept mission.
Those are the orders.

Fields.MenuText: So let's get going.
They'll be okay, Belfast. They know what they're doing.
All we can do is our job, Belfast.

Fields.DialogueText: I... yes, Captain. Under way.
I know.
Okay. Okay, you're right. We do it fast.
@BATTLE
Is it okay for me to be on the bridge? I haven't really been able to figure out what's going on.
The good news is that we haven't come across any new dolphin spies since the facility blew. So maybe that little atrocity is behind us.
The other news is that a Morgana fleet seems to be heading more or less straight for North Uist.
The people who we were hoping to slow them down...
... Well, they tried.
This wouldn't have happened if I hadn't wanted to save the dolphins.

Fields.MenuText: That's enough. You're not the one who gives the orders, Belfast.
Yeah, because a massive collection of Morganas was just going to sit around doing nothing indefinitely.
The dolphins were worth saving.

Fields.DialogueText: But...
Oh, good. I was just thinking that I really needed a jolt of sarcasm to get me past my guilt.
... Yes. Yes, they were.
You have nothing to feel guilty about. Nothing.
I know. I'm sorry. I just... I'm sorry.
Nothing to be sorry about, either. We'd all just be swimming without you, Belfast.
Well, what about North Uist? Can we do anything?
First we have to destroy these Morgana stragglers that want to slow us down.
You have my permission to engage.
@BATTLE
... Hmm.
The good news is that the Morganas seem to have changed course away from North Uist.
And the bad news is something terrible?

Fields.MenuText: Depends on how fond you are of Lewis.
The Morganas are going for Lewis.
Apparently they thought North Uist wasn't heavily populated enough.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain...
Oh, no.
They're... what, they're attacking Lewis?
We can't completely evacuate Stornoway, or any of the other coastal settlements, but they're trying to get as many people as possible down toward Harris.
Morganas and mountains are thought not likely to mix.
As for us, we're going to get as close as we can to Shawbost Beach in the northwest. Our Royal Marines will extract anyone who's gathered there.
We don't have that much room for civilians, Captain. I can try to...
Don't worry. I don't expect us to get many. Again, these are people who didn't pack up for Harris but want to leave anyway.
Understood. But I'll try to find enough space for them to be comfortable.
They'll appreciate it.
Of course, to get there, we're going to have to punch through the Morganas.
They're spread pretty thin in the region, but I think we're going to know we were in a fight.
@BATTLE
I suppose that's how we know we're doing our job. All ahead full, then...
Captain? Is this a good time?
Well, we're trying to find a way to get a bunch of civilians – yourself included, by the way – to Glasgow. And the Morganas are making it just about impossible.
Shooting could start at any minute.
But, sure, as long as it's quick.
You know that Belfast is down with some of the refugees from Lewis. She's singing to the children, actually.

Fields.MenuText: She has a nice voice.
It's okay. She can do that and guide the guns at the same time.
If this is about her hypothetical angelic nature, it won't be quick, and I don't have time.

Fields.DialogueText: She does. I wish she could use it like this more often. Under better circumstances.
Well, hooray for that, I suppose. It's funny, though.
Hm.
For all she can do, I don't think I ever really thought she was an angel. I definitely don't now.
The Morganas are building God knows what in the Hebrides, and all we can do is run. And... and...
Belfast's a very brave girl, and she's in over her head. You treat her like she's an officer, but...
Stop. You should probably...
You should probably know that I can hear everything on this ship and I can be anywhere on it at any time.
Yes. That. But you should probably also leave the bridge. We're not sneaking past the Morganas.
Action stations?
Please.
@BATTLE
The nerve of Joanna!
Please stop.
I'm doing everything I can to help the best crew in any fleet anywhere fight off an unending supply of monster ships.
I know.
"Brave girl."
She's a civilian, Belfast. She's scared out of her mind. She may not act like it, but she is.
She was trying to protect you because that's all there was for her to do. It's patronizing, but she doesn't mean any harm. I'm sure she feels bad about it now.
Why did you let her stay?
Her godfather's an admiral.
Uh-huh. Why did you really let her stay?
Maybe I wanted to know if the Belles were angels.
Maybe I thought it would help you if somebody seriously asked you the question.
It's hard to be a crew member's friend when you're captain. Sometimes you have to delegate the important things. You have to...
You said once that it's complicated being you, and at the time I didn't really think it was my place to say how damn good you are at it. But this would be a lousy war without you.
It's hard to be a captain's friend, too. Just so you know. Pretending your orders make sense all the time...

Fields.MenuText: Be honest, now. I'm worth it.
I know. I'm sorry for that.
Well, thank you for making the effort.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll see how much paint you cost me in our next battle.
It's okay. I think the crew all still think we know what we're doing, and that's what matters.
You're very welcome.
So, where are we going now? Assuming we get past the next Morganas?
I think we give up on Scotland and try bringing our refugees to Belfast. It's poetic, if nothing else.
Hm. I wish I could walk out and see the place.
Enh. It'll probably be raining, anyway.
@BATTLE
Raining shells.
Hello, Captain. Hello, Belfast.
Hi.
Miss Sheridan. We've put together a plan to get the civilian population to safety – in the other Belfast – and we wanted to be sure to say goodbye to you before it started.
I know. Belfast and I talked about it while I was coming to the bridge.
... Of course you did.
So you know we're not going to take you the whole way to Belfast Lough. You'll be transferred to another ship, and we'll block the Morganas that have been following us.
They've been collecting reinforcements along the way. If they chase us all the way to the city...
My whole family's there. You don't have to tell me.
So this is good-bye?

Fields.MenuText: I'm afraid so.
Thank God, right?
Well, unless something goes horribly wrong at the last minute. It's been known to happen.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd think you might be secretly grateful. Or not so secretly, really. I know I've been a nuisance.
Ha!
I have noticed that.
Well... thank you both for the hospitality. And for keeping me alive.
And, Belfast? Those of us back home like you more than Bulldog. For the record.
Aww. I promise I'll write.
Me, too.
Hey. "For which cause we faint not; but though our outward man perish, yet the inward man is renewed day by day."
"For our light affliction, which is but for a moment, worketh for us a far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory..."
"... while we look not at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen..."
Showoffs.
I suppose you're okay, too, Captain.
That's not getting you out of your poker debts.
@BATTLE
Dear me. Only these Morganas could solve that problem.
Captain?
Hold fire, Belfast. Let's get a little bit closer to the Morganas before we start spending ammunition.
It's not that, Captain. Not exactly.
The men in the radio room... they say something's cut into the BBC broadcast.
Something. Nazis?
A woman's voice. Apparently, the official position of the British government is that she's a saboteur.
Well, that's fantastic. What's she saying?
The same thing, over and over again. "Belfast took from me. I will take from Belfast. There must be a trade."
... What?

Fields.MenuText: You seem to have made a friend.
A Morgana? Did a Morgana actually take one of our actions personally?
I think they're targeting the city.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes.
I'm afraid you're right. I'm afraid these Morganas are raiding Belfast to get back at us. At me.
Captain, how do I fix this?
Well, I can tell you how we start.
@BATTLE
Don't be afraid, sailors. Just believe!
@BATTLE
All clear.
Are you all right, Captain?
Yeah. Banged my head on that last swell, but I have a famously thick skull.
Is it just me, or does it really seem like the Morganas have their hearts set on attacking Belfast? The city, I mean.
They're just not letting up. They're not gaining much by it. They're not targeting things they can use to improve themselves.
They're just attacking. It's the monster ship equivalent of spitting in our faces.
Are we missing something? Or is this just a bunch of suicide attacks until we break? What are they doing?
Did Joanna ever tell you about her message in a bottle?
No. Metaphorical or literal?
Literal. Questions she wanted the Morganas to answer. She wrote a nice letter like the one she originally sent me, she put it in a bottle, and then she threw it over my side.

Fields.MenuText: I hope somebody lets me know if they agree to an interview.
I take it she was drunk?
Well, let's hope that one doesn't find a way to turn around and bite us.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, don't worry. I'm sure we'll get the newsreel.
How often do you suppose she's sober?
Yes, because we're traditionally so lucky that way.
I wonder if the Morganas are what happen to Belles if you take away captain and crew. If nobody's around to keep us grounded. So to speak.
I ordinarily like the ideas that make me sound important, but I doubt it. I don't think you have that particular kind of crazy in you.
Still, let's never find out.
Captain?
You know I've been talking to some of our friends from London?
I try not to eavesdrop on the radio room. Should I be worried?
Probably. The consensus is that the Morganas are pulling together forces for one last major attack on Belfast.
They're still scattered, though. If we seek them out and hit the smaller groups before they unite, it might almost be manageable.
When you say smaller groups...

Fields.MenuText: Tiny. Would I lie?
Oh, each one's almost certainly bigger than the force that took Lewis.
Yeah, I don't think any single one of them will outnumber us by more than a factor of two or three.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. Please continue.
I like how calmly you say that.
I'm profoundly relieved.
Timing is going to be everything. We won't be leaving Northern Ireland totally undefended, but if Morgana groups two and three outrace us while we're dealing with group one...
I'll be at my fastest, Captain. I promise.
I know. I'd scrounge up some other Belles, but I really think having you on point will make it more likely that these particular groups will engage rather than try to slip by.
But I know we've been working you harder than most. If you...
I think it's an awful, awful plan, and I'm proud to be a part of it.
Well, then, we might as well start heading south by southwest. I'll break out the charts and we'll see exactly where these idiots were last sighted.
@BATTLE
Something tells me we're not going to have to look very hard.
We're coming up along the Lofoten Islands, Captain.
Understood. I want everyone to keep their eyes open.
Group Three was last sighted near the Faroes. If we can't catch Group Two here, we can be pretty sure they'll rendezvous, and then we've got a hell of a mess on our hands.
Did you actually get any sleep last night?
I'll sleep after the war. How about you?
I don't sleep.
I know. But as I think back to the ancient days of about two weeks ago, I'd swear you were known to rest.
Pf. I'll rest when I'm a museum ship.

Fields.MenuText: That's the plan?

Fields.DialogueText: Either that or cruising the Mediterranean and looking for handsome schooners.
And I've spotted Group Two.
Okay, then.
@BATTLE
Done. Up for another sprint?
Sometimes I really do miss the days when I had time to wonder what my purpose was.
I miss the days when I almost believed you when you said it didn't hurt getting shot up.
Ha.
Get us to your namesake. Fast as we can go.

Fields.MenuText: There are certainly worse fates.

Fields.DialogueText: None better.

Fields.MenuText: You don't want to go out in a blaze of glory?

Fields.DialogueText: I do believe in Heaven, Captain, but I'm in no hurry to get there.
Listening for dolphins?
Oh, I warned them all off hours ago. They were very grateful.
... You're talking to dolphins now.
To be honest, they don't usually listen very hard. But that's okay.
I'll take your word for it.
So. It's a good day for a life-and-death battle to save an entire city. Nice breeze.
Are you ready?
Yes. I've had an epiphany, actually – though you probably knew it all along.
I'm not an angel. I'm not a brave girl.
I'm a light cruiser. My skin is two inches of steel at its thinnest and my fists are 2-pounder guns.
And I will break the things that are trying to hurt my friends into so many pieces that God Himself couldn't find them all in a day.

Fields.MenuText: Good speech. A little wordy, but it had heart.
Okay. For the record, if I hadn't already been willing to follow you into Hell itself, that would've done it.

Fields.DialogueText: More sacrilegious than I'd intended, but it was okay.
Let's hope that's not necessary.
After we win the war against the Morganas, I'm sure God will understand.
